title: 104_s1582
content: The "Runaway and Homeless Youth Reauthorization Act of 1996" amends the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974 to authorize appropriations. The "Runaway and Homeless Youth Reauthorization Act of 1996" authorizes appropriations of $75,000,000 for fiscal years 1997-2000, with 90% allocated to section 311(a) and $911,700 reserved for section 331. Programs may receive enhancement grants to improve performance standards. The "Runaway and Homeless Youth Reauthorization Act of 1996" authorizes appropriations for various purposes, including increasing trained staff, strengthening family reunification efforts, improving aftercare services, coordinating services with public and private entities, providing comprehensive services, and enhancing data collection efforts. Funds in excess of $42,599,999 can be used for developing new programs in underserved communities and program enhancement activities. Authorized appropriations for fiscal years 1997-2000: $25,000,000 for part B and $1,000,000 for section 344. Coordination between Administration on Children, Youth and Families and Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention is required for program development and implementation. The text chunk discusses the appropriation of funds for programs authorized under specific titles and acts, emphasizing that funds must be used only for authorized programs. Additionally, it mentions an amendment to the Missing Children's Assistance section of the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974. The text chunk authorizes appropriations for various programs under specific titles and acts, specifying funding amounts for fiscal years 1997-2000. This includes grants for local delinquency prevention programs and drug education relating to youth gangs. SEC. 3505 and SEC. 3513 authorize appropriations of $16,000,000 for fiscal years 1997-2000 for specific programs. SEC. 4 of the Crime Control Act of 1990 also authorizes appropriations. Authorization of appropriations for sections 213, 214, and 214A is set at $15,000,000 and $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 1997 to 2000.
